bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia was created by an act of the General Assembly passed at the May 1779 session and has continued to the present day. Its antecedent was the General Court, which, after it was reestablished under the constitution of 1776, shared appellate jurisdiction with the Supreme Court until 1851, when the new state constitution abolished the General Court. Prior to that date the General Court had criminal jurisdiction, while the Supreme Court was restricted to civil cases. While the court now has concurrent original jurisdiction in issuing and hearing writs of habeas corpus, mandamus and prohibition, retirement, removal, and matters of judicial censure, its jurisdiction is almost exclusively appellate. An act of the General Assembly passed on March 16, 1971 changed the name of the court to the Supreme Court of Virginia.

Justices are elected by a majority vote of both houses of the General Assembly for a term of twelve years. Vacancies on the court occuring between sessions of the General Assembly may be filled by the Governor for a term expiring thirty days after the commencement of the next session of the General Assembly. By statute, the Chief Justice is chosen by a majority vote of the seven justices.

By statute, the court by designate a retired justice to serve as Senior Justice for a renewable one year term. Senior Justices sit with the court during regular sessions hearing writs and sitting on merit cases, especially when an active member of the court is recused from hearing a particular case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: These recording include audio and visual recordings of court ceremonies and oral history interviews, 1969-2015.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into the following series:

list.item: Series I. Audio and Audio-Visual recordings of court ceremonies, 1991-2011

did.unittitle: Series I. Audio and Audio-Visual recordings of court ceremonies,, 1991-2011.

scopecontent.p: This series contains 21 video recordings of Supreme Court of Virginia ceremonies, 1991-2011, and one video recording of a Court of Appeals of Virginia ceremony, 2008. Includes investitures and swearing-in ceremonies, portrait presentation ceremonies, as well as other court ceremonies. The ceremonies took place in the courtroom in Richmond unless otherwise noted.

Investiture of Barbara Milano Keenan as justice of the Supreme Court of Virginia, Courtroom 5-E, Fairfax Judicial Center in Fairfax, Virginia, 1991 July 2. Includes one video recording of the entire ceremony with poor audio (43 minutes) and two segments of the television show Law Weekly (60 minutes), a production of the Fairfax County Bar Association, moderated by Glenn C. Lewis, with highlights of the ceremony and interviews with guests. The segments were broadcast on the Fairfax County public access television station, FCAC Channel 10. The ceremony was the first televised session of the Supreme Court. Chief Justice Carrico, presiding; with remarks by Raymond Diaz, president of the Virginia State Bar; William D. Dolan, III, past president of the Virginia State Bar; Governor L. Douglas Wilder; Speaker of the House A. L. Philpott; State Senator Edward M. Holland; State Senator Richard L. Saslow; Retired Judge Arthur W. Sinclair; Virginia Court of Appeals Judge Johanna Fitzpatrick; and Justice Keenan. The second segment of the recording features host Glenn Lewis interviewing guests Emilie Miller, Virginia State Senator; Fairfax County Commonwealth's Attorney Robert H. Horan; Chief Justice Carrico; Virginia Court of Appeals Judge Charles H. Duff; William Dolan, Raymond Diaz, Judge Sinclair, Judge Richard T. Horan, Justice Keenan, Ann Milano, retired Clerk Delores Testerman, Judith Wheat, and Jerry Phillips. Barbara M. Keenan served on the Supreme Court of Virginia from 1991 to 2010, when she was confirmed as a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. She was a judge on the Court of Appeals of Virginia from 1985 to 1991. She was the first woman to serve as circuit and appellate court judge in Virginia.

Investiture of Lawrence L. Koontz, Jr., as justice of the Supreme Court of Virginia, Olin Hall, Roanoke College, Salem, Virginia, 1995 August 16 (49 minutes and 30 seconds). Chief Justice Carrico, presiding; remarks by George W. Wooten; Judge Beverly T. Fitzpatrick; Michael Smith, president of the Virginia State Bar; Delegate C. Richard Cranwell; and Justice Koontz. Invocation and benediction by Rev. R. Paul Hendrickson, Chaplain, Roanoke College. The recording also includes clips of local television news coverage of the event (WDBJ News 7 and WSLS News 10). Lawrence L. Koontz, Jr., served on the Supreme Court of Virginia from 1995 to 2011, when he took senior status. He was a judge on the Court of Appeals of Virginia from 1985 to 1995.

Investiture of Cynthia Fannon Kinser as justice of the Supreme Court of Virginia, Lee High School, Jonesville, Virginia, 1997 July 8 (1 hour, 32 minutes). Chief Justice Carrico, presiding; remarks by Governor George Allen; Senior Judge Glenn Williams, U.S. District Court, Western District of Virginia; Justice Kinser, and others. The recording includes footage before and after the ceremony and the following reception. Cynthia Dinah Fannon Kinser was appointed to the Supreme Court of Virginia in 1997. She was elected chief justice August 31, 2010, effective February 10, 2010. She is the first woman to serve as chief justice.

Ceremony honoring Chief Justice Harry L. Carrico upon his retirement from full-time service, 2003 January 1 (43 minutes, 18 seconds). Poor quality video recording. Chief Justice Hassell, presiding; remarks by Robert N. Baldwin, Executive Secretary; and Justice Donald W. Lemons; presentation of slideshow with photographs of family and court staff. Harry L. Carrico (1916-2013) served on the Supreme Court of Virginia, 1961-2003, and was chief justice, 1981-2003. He took senior status in 2003.

Swearing-in ceremony of Justice Leroy R. Hassell, Sr., as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Virginia, 2003 February 11 (45 seconds). Justice Barbara M. Keenan administering the oath of office, with Chief Justice Hassell's wife, Linda Hassell, holding the Bible. Leroy Rountree Hassell, Sr. (1955-2011) was appointed to the Supreme Court of Virginia in 1989 and served until his death in 2011. He was elected to a four-year term as Chief Justice in 2003 and reelected in 2007. He was the first African American to serve as Chief Justice.

Investiture of G. Steven Agee as justice of the Supreme Court of Virginia, recorded at Roanoke College in Salem, Va., 2003 March 5 (1 hour, 5 minutes, and 35 seconds). Chief Justice Hassel, presiding; remarks by State Senator Charles Hawkins, Delegate Robert McDonnell, Attorney General Jerry Kilgore, Delegate Lacy Putney, and Justice Agee. G. Steven Agee served on the Supreme Court of Appeals from 2003-2008, when he was appointed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Previously, he was judge on the Court of Appeals of Virginia, 2001-2003.

Ceremony honoring David Beach upon his retirement from the position of Clerk, Supreme Court of Virginia, 2003 June 1 (47 minutes). Chief Justice Hassell, presiding; remarks by Senior Justice Harry L. Carrico; U.S. District Court Judge John A. Gibney; Justice Elizabeth B. Lacy; Trish Harrington, Clerk, Supreme Court of Virginia; Robert N. Baldwin, Executive Secretary, Supreme Court of Virginia; and David Beach. David Beach was Clerk of the Supreme Court of Virginia, 1984-2003.

Ceremony honoring Robert N. Baldwin upon his retirement from the position of Executive Secretary, Supreme Court of Virginia, 2005 March 31 (1 hour, 11 minutes, 51 seconds). Chief Justice Hassell, presiding; remarks by Bill Howell, Speaker of the House; Chief Judge, Court of Appeals of Virginia, Johanna Fitzpatrick; James Ullman, former chair, House Courts Committee; Retired Judge J.R. Zepkin, Judge Phillip Trompeter, and Larry Palmer, Clerk, Lynchburg Circuit Court. Robert N. Baldwin was Executive Secretary for the Supreme Court of Virginia, 1976-2005
